attributes.action: bring entertainment goods, such as CD and DVDs, in line with those prices charged in North America and Asia.
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
Recently, £41 million in damages has been awarded against an Asian CD retailer for selling Asian versions of CDs to UK customers.

Prices for CDs sold by this company were as low as £4.99 for some of the most popular modern artists' albums, however in the UK the average CD price is £8.50 (according to the BPI website).

Another example is that a large American supermarket sells music downloads for $0.88 (£0.44 at 29/5/07). In the UK, the cheapest music downloads are around £0.70 - an increase of almost 60% compared to the American price.

Why are we, the British people, being charged extra for exactly the same product? This is not due to taxes or the exchange rate, but rather the record companies attempting to make as much money as possible from Britain.
